I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
of up to $18,400,000 to Champion Agro Limited for the Horticulture Cold Chain Project in India. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

2. 
Rural  poverty  remains  an  acute  development  problem  in  India.  In  2009–2010,  rural 
poverty incidence stood at 33.8% (as opposed to 20.9% in urban areas). India is still home to 
some 280 million rural poor.1 While agriculture remains the main source of rural livelihood, rural 
poverty  can  also  be  reduced  through  the  expansion  of  post-harvest  operations  and  food 
processing,  which  provide  both  market  linkages  to  farmers  and  nonfarm  employment. 2 
Horticulture  specifically  represents  a  strong  opportunity  for  poverty  reduction.  Horticulture  is 
considered a type of high-value agriculture as it gives a higher rate of return to farmers per unit 
of land than the production of staple crops. It can also sustain agro-industries, which generate 
substantial  employment. The World  Bank  estimated that  year-round, full-time employment  can 
be generated by a one-hectare shift from cereal to vegetable in one planting season.3 
 
3. 
Horticulture in India has grown significantly in recent years. While staple crop production 
has grown by 2.8% a year during 2007–2012, horticulture production has grown at 4.7% in the 
same  period  (footnote  2).  The  horticulture  sector  now  contributes  about  28%  of  agricultural 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  from  about  13%  of  the  area  under  cultivation.  Demand  for 
horticulture  products  is  likely  to  continue  to  grow  even  faster  on  account  of  both  internal  and 
external demand. The consumer basket in India is undergoing changes, with preference shifting 
to perishables such as fruits, vegetables, and dairy products. As the second largest producer of 
fruits  and vegetables  in the  world  (after the  People’s  Republic  of  China),  India is  also  a major 
exporter.4 Horticulture represents 37% of the total exports of agricultural commodities.5   
 
Horticulture  production,  however,  remains  constrained  by  the  weak  post-harvest  and 
4. 
market  infrastructure  and  the  fragmentation  in  value  chains  and  production  systems.  These 
result  in  high  post-harvest  wastage  of  fresh  produce  estimated  to  be  about  35%  of  total 
production—equivalent  to  Rs350  billion  in  value  terms—and  very  low  processing. 6  The 
inadequate facilities for storage also result in considerable fluctuations in the price of products 
through  the  season  (footnote  2).  These  key  constraints  can  be  addressed  through  upgrading 
both public and private agribusiness infrastructure and supporting value chain aggregators and 
food processors. Accordingly, post-harvest and cold storage facilities have been included in the 
government’s definition of infrastructure to provide incentives to the financial sector. 
 
5. 
In June 2012, Champion Agro Limited approached Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
financing  a  $22.8 million  investment,  over  2  years,  for  a  horticulture  cold  chain  project.  The

 2 

 

project is central to the company’s strategy of adding value to the production of fresh fruits and 
vegetables, improving supply chain efficiency, and expanding access to customers in key cities. 
The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  nonsovereign  strategic  agenda  of  pursuing  agribusiness 
investments with high potential for developmental impact. Champion Agro was found to be one 
of the most reputable agribusiness sponsors in India, creditworthy, and well placed to leverage 
ADB’s funds toward development. 
 
6. 
The project is fully consistent with the objectives of India’s Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2012–
2017 for the farm sector: (i) higher productivity in farming; (ii) higher value for farming; and (iii) a 
major expansion of post-harvest activities, including storage and processing. To achieve these 
goals,  the  plan  calls  for  (i)  developing  integrated  value  chains  for  high-value  segments  of 
agriculture;  (ii)  encouraging  private  investment  in  cold  chain  and  food  processing;  (iii)  linking 
small  farmers  with  markets  through  producer  companies  and  corporate  retailers;  and  (iv) 
continuing with policy reforms allowing private sector markets and contract farming (footnote 2). 
 

2. 

Project Design 

7. 
The  project  will  have  the  following  four  components  across  the  horticulture  cold  chain: 
(i) five  collection  centers,  (ii)  a  controlled  atmosphere  cold  storage  facility,  (iii)  an  individually 
quick frozen facility, and (iv) five distribution centers. The project will support Champion Agro’s 
horticulture business from the collection of fresh fruits and vegetables from farmers in Gujarat to 
their distribution to corporate clients in large Indian cities and abroad. 
 
8. 
Champion Agro will set up five collection centers in Gujarat (Navsari, Junagadh, Prantij, 
Rajpipla, and Borsad), with total capacity of 50,000 tons of fruits and vegetables per year. Each 
center  will  include  (i)  a  cleaning,  grading,  and  packing  line;  (ii)  a  pre-cooling  chamber;  (iii)  a 
holding  cold  store;  (iv)  a  warehouse;  and  (v)  reefer  vans.  The  collection  centers  will  be 
strategically located near farms. The major produce collected will be bananas and mangos.   
 
9. 
The controlled atmosphere cold storage facility will be located in Palanpur (Gujarat) and 
will have a capacity of 5,000 tons of fruits and vegetables per year. It will provide long duration 
storage for fruits and vegetables to ensure the smooth supply of the produce when the supply is 
low and the demand is high and to reduce food wastage. The facility will include (i) a pre-cooling 
chamber;  (ii)  a  holding  cold  store;  and  (iii)  a  controlled  atmosphere  cold  store  (in  which 
temperature,  humidity,  and  concentration  of  oxygen  and  carbon  dioxide  are  regulated).  The 
major produce stored will be apples, pears, oranges, lemons, and pomegranates. 
 
10. 
The individually quick frozen facility will be located in Gundasara (Gujarat), with capacity 
of 8,000 tons of fruits and vegetables per year. The individually quick frozen technology (often 
referred  as  IQF)  is  a  food  preservation  technology  where  fresh  food  passes  through  the  low 
temperature zone very quickly, leaving very low and safe microbial counts. The major produce 
processed will be sweet corn, green peas, green vegetables, mango cubes, and papaya cubes. 
The  majority  of  the  produce  (around  70%)  will  be  exported.  At  least  five  important  ports  are 
located within a radius of 150–200 kilometers of Gundasara. 
 
11. 
Champion  Agro  will  set  up  five  distribution  centers  in  large  cities  of  Northern  India 
(Ahmedabad, Jaipur, Delhi, Ludhiana, and Panchkula), with capacity of 60,000 tons of produce 
per  year.  The  distribution  centers  will  service  supermarket  wholesalers  (e.g.,  Bharti,  Walmart, 
Carrefour,  Future  Fresh,  Reliance  Fresh,  and  Safal)  and  food  processors  in  areas  of  large 
demand  for  fruits  and  vegetables.  The  centers  will  source  produce  from  the  company’s 
collection centers and controlled atmosphere cold storage facilities, as well as local producers. 

  

3 

Each center will include (i) a cleaning, grading, and packing line; (ii) a pre-cooling chamber; and 
(iii) a holding cold store. The major produce stored for final distribution will be bananas. 
 
12. 
ADB’s commercial and technical consultant visited the proposed locations and confirmed 
the suitability of the areas in terms of existing and potential horticulture production; proximity to 
markets; availability of workers; and access to roads, water, and electricity. 
 

3. 

The Borrower 

13. 
Champion  Agro  is  a  leading  Indian  agribusiness  company  from  Gujarat.  Established  in 
1990,  the  company  was  originally  named  Magnetic  Industries  and  its  initial  business  was  the 
manufacturing  of  agricultural  irrigation  systems.  In  2005,  the  company  devised  the  concept  of 
agro retail malls—one-stop shops for farmers selling agricultural inputs (e.g., seeds, pesticides, 
and  fertilizers)  and  equipment  (e.g.,  farm  machinery,  greenhouses,  and  irrigation  systems).  In 
2008,  the  company  entered  into  the  processing  of  fresh  fruits  and  vegetables,  supported  by 
contract farming and leased farmland.7 In 2010, the company renamed itself Champion Agro to 
reflect the company’s new core business focus on agribusiness. 
 
14. 
Champion Agro is a unique agribusiness player in India, in that it is fully integrated from 
the provision of agricultural inputs to farmers up to the delivery of fresh fruits and vegetables to 
corporate retailers. The company owns a chain of 44 agro retail malls in Gujarat, and has plans 
to  scale  up  this  model  in  selected  Indian  states.  Champion  Agro  is  directly  involved  in 
agricultural activities, with about 5,000 hectares under lease farming and about 12,000 hectares 
under  contract 
the  cultivation  of  seeds 
in  Gujarat.  The  company  supports 
(e.g., chickpea, peanut, and sesame) to supply its agro retail malls, along with fresh fruits and 
vegetables  that  are  bought  back  to  be  processed  and  distributed.  The  company  owns  and 
leases  processing,  storage,  and  distribution  facilities  across  several  Indian  states  (Gujarat, 
Himachal Pradesh, and Delhi). Other businesses of the company include cattle feed production, 
manufacturing of irrigation pumps and greenhouses, and farm services (testing, consultancy). 
 
15. 
Champion Agro directly employs about 200 people, including at least 170 with university 
education in agronomy and agribusiness. In addition, about 8,500 farmers work under contract 
and  lease  farming  with  the  company;  15,000  have  been  trained  in  scientific  crop  cultivation 
practices, and 40,000 have benefited from the company’s consultancy services.  
 
B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Output  

farming 

1. 

Impacts  

16. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  increased  horticulture  growth  in  India.  According  to  the 
objectives in the Twelfth Five Year Plan, horticulture production growth will increase to 6.5% per 
year during the Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2012–2017 from 4.8% per year during the Eleventh Five 
Year  Plan,  2007–2012  (footnotes  1  and  2).  The  project  will  contribute  to  private  sector 
development by promoting an increase in lending for pre- and post-harvest activities (a priority 
sector monitored by the Reserve Bank of India) from Rs146 billion in FY2011 to at least Rs400 
billion in FY2017.8 As such, the project will contribute to a reduction in post-harvest wastage of

fruits  and  vegetables,  although  this  impact  is  hard  to  quantify  (wastage  is  currently  estimated 
between 6% and 35%). Reduction in post-harvest wastage will contribute to more efficient use 
of  water  resources.  India  is  one  of  the  most  water-stressed  countries  in  the  world,  and  most 
water  demand  comes  from  agriculture.  Reduction  in  post-harvest  wastage  and  more  water-
efficient agriculture are essential to meeting the impending water crisis in India.  
 
17. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  a  reduction  in  rural  poverty  in  Gujarat  from  26.7%  in 
FY2010 to 20.0% by FY2017, in line with the Twelfth Five Year Plan’s national poverty reduction 
objectives,  by  including  farmers  in  the  horticulture  value  chain.9 According  to  a  recent  paper, 
formal value chains ―tend to provide greater income security but not necessarily higher prices. 
When higher incomes do occur, it is often from higher yields, improved quality, or value-added 
activities.‖ 10 This  is  where  an  integrated company like  Champion  Agro  can  make  a difference. 
Through its agro retail malls, consultancy services, and contract farming, Champion Agro helps 
farmers focus on high-value crops, increase in yields, and improvements in the quality of their 
produce. Processing and storage activities add value to the produce. Finally, the elimination of 
intermediaries can help farmers capture a higher share of the final price paid by the consumer. 
According  to  Champion  Agro,  an  incremental  income  of  about  35%–50%  accrues  to  farmers 
from  an  association  with  the  company.11 ADB  will  consider  conducting  a  distribution  analysis 
during project implementation to validate the direct poverty reduction benefits of the project, as 
well as its gender inclusion benefits given the importance of women in agricultural production. 
 
18. 
Finally, the project will contribute to improved nutrition in India. A minimum of 400 grams 
of fruits and vegetables per day is recommended for the prevention of chronic diseases and the 
alleviation  of  micronutrient  deficiencies.12 In  India,  only  15%  of  the  population  consumed  this 
daily minimum in 2005.13 The project is expected to contribute to an increase in that proportion.  
 

2. 

Outcome 

The project’s expected outcome will be increased processing and distribution of quality 
19. 
fruits and vegetables sourced from local farmers and supported by technical assistance from the 
company  on  high-yield  water-efficient  technologies.  Champion  Agro’s  sales  of  fruits  and 
vegetables are expected to increase from about $2.6 million in FY2012 to at least $18.3 million 
in FY2017. The number of company’s employees is expected to increase from 200 in FY2012 to 
at  least  300  in  FY2017. The  number  of farmers working  with  the  company  under  contract  and 
lease  farming  is  expected  to  increase  from  8,500  in  FY2012  to  15,000  in  FY2017.  The  land 
converted to high-yield water-efficient agriculture is expected to increase from 12,000 hectares 
in FY2012 to 20,000 hectares in FY2017.14 Higher yields will be achieved through better water 
management  and  more  efficient  irrigation  systems,  better  seed  selection  and  better  usage  of 
pesticides, and soil and water testing to determine the optimum utilization of agricultural inputs.

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 

According  to  Strategy  2020,  supporting  agriculture  is  an  ―underlying  component  of  the 
21. 
inclusive  growth  strategy‖  because  ―the  majority  of  the  poor  still  live  in  rural  areas,  and 
agriculture  remains  a  source  of  productivity  improvement,  seasonal  employment,  and  income 
growth—especially  when  connected  to  urban,  industrial,  and  export  markets.‖15 As  such,  the 
project  is  particularly  relevant  because  Champion  Agro  is  connecting  farmers  to  urban 
consumers and export markets. The project is also consistent with Strategy 2020’s objective of 
scaling up private sector development and private sector operations in all operational areas. 
 
Under the forthcoming country partnership strategy for India, 2013–2017, agribusiness is 
22. 
one of the sectors to be supported by the Private Sector Operations Department: ―ADB’s private 
sector  operations  will  explore  new  investments  in  agribusiness  to  support  the  government’s 
strategy of developing integrated value chains for high-value segments of agriculture and linking 
small  farmers  with  markets.‖  The  forthcoming  country  partnership  strategy  also  insists  on  the 
critical need to improve agribusiness infrastructure to reduce post-harvest losses and increase 
value-adding  processing  through  the  ―aggregation  of  horticulture  produce,  post-harvest  (e.g., 
grading,  sorting,  and  packaging),  storage,  and  market  facilities  in  a  more  integrated  manner 
employing an integrated value chain approach.‖ (footnote 1) 
 

2. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 

The  project  is  fully  aligned  with  ADB’s  agriculture  sector  strategy.  In  particular,  the 
23. 
Operational  Plan  for  Sustainable  Food  Security,  2009  recommends  an  ―expanded  partnership 
with  the  private  sector‖  to  attract  ―more  direct  investments  in  productivity  enhancement,  agro-
processing,  agro-retailing  and  other  nonfarm  rural  business.‖  The  project  also  addresses  the 
operational  plan’s  objective  of  ―increasing  synergy  and  value  addition  in  the  backward  and 
forward linkages along the food and agriculture value chain.‖ Improved linkages along the value 
chain enhance productivity, employment opportunities, exports and regional trade, but also food 
security for the poor in both rural and urban areas.16  
 
24. 
Horticulture has been the focus of ADB’s sovereign assistance to the Indian agriculture 
sector since 2010. ADB funded horticulture value chain studies and investment projects in Bihar 
and  Maharashtra. 17  An  ongoing  South  Asia  Department  study  involves  a  review  of  the 
horticulture  value  chain  in  six  other  Indian  states.  Since  Gujarat  is  one  of  the  selected  states, 
the  South  Asia  Department  agreed  to  involve  Champion  Agro  in  this  study,  allowing  for

F. 

Unique Features 

28. 
The  project  promotes  inclusive  agricultural  value  chains.  Champion  Agro  will  assist 
farmers in switching to high-value horticulture cultivation and in reducing post-harvest losses. By 
entering into contract farming arrangements with farmers and providing them with post-harvest 
infrastructure, Champion Agro will link farmers to markets for fresh fruits and vegetables in India 
and  abroad.  The  project  will  also  promote  formal  employment  in  the  cold  chain  sector.  This 
project will be ADB’s first nonsovereign agribusiness project in India. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

The proposed assistance is a senior secured loan of $18.4 million. 

29.  
 
B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

30.   ADB  will  provide  long-term  fixed-rate  financing,  which  is  not  readily  available  in  this 
sector.  ADB’s  assistance will  contribute to  raising the  profile of  a  medium-sized company  with 
strong  growth  potential.  As  Champion  Agro  becomes  larger,  Indian  commercial  banks—which 
are  already  providing  short-term  working  capital  loans  to  the  company—will  be  expected  to 
replace ADB as providers of long-term loans to finance the company’s capital expenditures. The 
project  will  have  synergies  with  ADB’s  public  sector  support  to  the  horticulture  sector  in  India, 
and  will  contribute  to  the  government’s  objectives  of  promoting  private  sector  investment  and 
employment in high-value agriculture and agribusiness infrastructure. ADB’s assistance will also 
promote  the  adoption  of  environmental  and  social  best  practices  in  the  sector.  Overall,  the 
project  will  set  an  example  for  private  sector-led  horticulture  cold  chain  investments  in  other 
developing member countries, which will benefit from the lessons learned in India.
